top_comments_top.body:
Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.

I made the mistake of introducing myself to the professor of a large lecture class back when I was in college. She called on me every day to answer things because mine was the only name she knew. Here's an LPT: wait until you know a bit more about the class and instructor before deciding if knowing them on a one-on-one level is something you really want.

OP says "as a general rule" and because of that, I'd agree. Faculty mostly want to help you, and even more so if you're a relatable human who is clearly trying your best.

I'm a professor (22 years in). I want to help my students, but I'm not extra-motivated to do so if they won't help themselves (I am still *normally* motivated, though!). Be real with me and I'll do what's fair and reasonable, and even more, to help you out.

I've given extensions to students who just straight up asked if they could make up Friday because game XXXXX is coming out Thursday. I get it, I would have appreciated that back when 16-bit graphics were cool. These students were honest and real. Just be real. Need a moment/day to collect yourself? Good by me, I've been posting my class sessions privately on YouTube for years, and can send you a link. Miss an assignment by a few hours? It's okay just don't make it a habit. In many classes (NOT all) a late assignment is better than no assignment.

A lot (not all, unfortunately... Maybe they're lizard people? [Joking!]) of your professors are also real people with real lives outside of work. Today at 8:30am I joined a work meeting early and watched a colleague playing "Here Comes the Sun" by The Beatles on a guitar he made himself. He was proud of his handiwork, and played really well, but he also wanted us early arrivals to hear something positive to start the meeting. Your professors really are real humans. Yes, even the douchebag ones.

Disclaimer: despite what you might have heard, faculty are generally pretty smart. Be real, not exploitative or fake, and don't lie. You *might* get scorched otherwise.

As a former college instructor, this is a great LPT. Also, circle back to former ones you like so that when/if you go asking for a recommendation letter the instructor/professor may be more willing to write you a great one.

top_comments_best.body:
Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment.

This depends om country, discipline and level of class, I'd say.
If you want to be the professor's friend, do your work well and turn it in on time and without drama.
